instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used for the geographical traceability of a fungus, specifically Wolfiporia cocos?

instruction: What metric was chosen for the geographical traceability of a fungus, specifically Wolfiporia cocos and how far can this metric go?

instruction: How were machine learning models utilized in the related study to achieve the purpose of evaluating the fusion strategy of multiple-information technologies for the geographical traceability of Wolfiporia cocos fungus?
Output:
In the related study, machine learning models were utilized to evaluate the fusion strategy of multiple-information technologies for the geographical traceability of Wolfiporia cocos fungus. The models used were extreme learning machine (ELM), partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA), and support vector machine (SVM).

The ELM model was found to have better geographical traceability compared to PLS-DA and SVM models. The accuracy of the training set for all models was 100%. The ELM model achieved 100% accuracy for both the train and test sets when using single spectrum, low-level fusion, and mid-level fusion of Fourier transform near infrared spectroscopy (FT-NIR) and Fourier-transform mid infrared spectroscopy (FT-MIR) based on principal components (PCs) and competitive adaptive weighting algorithm (CARS).

Additionally, the study also utilized the successive projection algorithm (SPA) for developing models. However, the three models based on SPA were not satisfactory for the geographical traceability of the fungus.

Overall, the machine learning models, particularly the ELM model, were employed to evaluate the fusion strategy of multiple-information technologies and determine the geographical traceability of Wolfiporia cocos fungus effectively.

instruction: How did the researchers evaluate the fusion strategy of multiple-information technologies for the geographical traceability of Wolfiporia cocos fungus using spectroscopic methods?
Output:

Firstly, they used t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) to visually compare the effectiveness of FT-NIR and FT-MIR spectroscopy. They found that FT-NIR spectroscopy had a superior effect in separating the samples from different regions.

Secondly, they compared the performance of different models for geographical traceability. Thirdly, they evaluated the accuracy of the ELM model with single spectrum, low-level fusion, and mid-level fusion of FT-NIR and FT-MIR using principal components (PCs) and competitive adaptive weighting algorithm (CARS).
